parts: Name this molecule commonly taken by athletes as a performance supplement. Originally isolated from muscle, high levels of this molecule’s kinase (“KAI-nase”) in the blood can indicate injuries or heart disease.

The clearance of creatine’s (“CREE-a-teen’s”) cyclic cousin creatinine (“cree-AT-in-neen”) can be measured to approximate this value. In early 2021, a joint statement by the ASN and NKF asserted that formulas for calculating this value should remove modifiers for a patient’s race.
The glomerular (“glo-MAIR-yu-lar”) filtration rate quantifies the health of these paired organs, which are responsible for moving waste from the blood into the urine.

The glomerular (“glo-MAIR-yu-lar”) filtration rate quantifies the health of these paired organs, which are responsible for moving waste from the blood into the urine.

bonuses.leadin: An exciting lab demo separating the contents of these objects can produce bands of rhodamine (“RHO-da-meen”) derivatives that have been activated by the decomposition of hydrogen peroxide. For 10 points each:

answers_sanitized: glow sticks [or light sticks; or chem lights; accept glow-matography]
parts: Name these single-use objects whose central reaction is thermally forbidden and thus does not produce heat.

“Glow-matography” can be done with a stick of chalk and acetone because calcium carbonate is ionic and thus has this property. In general, chromatography relies on a mobile phase with this property of having separated charge.

Glowsticks commonly use derivatives of this fourteen-carbon aromatic molecule as dyes. Oxidizing this molecule at the central 9 and 10 positions leaves two aromatic rings separated by carbonyls (“carbon-eels”).

“Glow-matography” can be done with a stick of chalk and acetone because calcium carbonate is ionic and thus has this property. In general, chromatography relies on a mobile phase with this property of having separated charge.

Glowsticks commonly use derivatives of this fourteen-carbon aromatic molecule as dyes. Oxidizing this molecule at the central 9 and 10 positions leaves two aromatic rings separated by carbonyls (“carbon-eels”).
